_header: Jesu for Thy holy name / And for Thy bitter Passion
Note: For a prose variant see London, British Library Addit. 33381, f. 181v.
Subjects: prayers, by the Holy Name; Christ, Holy Name of
_description: The popular prayer by the Holy Name — four lines, frequently followed by two more varying lines

BodRawC48.First Lines:
Iesu for thy holly name & for thy bytter
                    passyon…
BodRawC48.Last Lines:
…& from endlys damnacyon& bryng us to blys
                    þat neuer shall mys

BodGoughlit7.First Lines:
Ihesu for thy holy name & for thy bytter
                    passyon…
BodGoughlit7.Last Lines:
…And bryng vs to thy blysse that neuer shall haue ende swete
                    Ihesu

BodGoughlit3.First Lines: Ihesus for thy holi name and thy bytter paschon…
BodGoughlit3.Last Lines:
…and brynge me to thy blesse Ihesus haue mercy on
                    me

BodDou54.Transcription:
Ihesu for thy holy nameAnd for thy bytter passyonSaue vs from
                    syn and schameAnd from endles damnacounAnd bryng vs to þi
                    blyssewhych neuer schal mysse

BodRawlitf36.Transcription:
IHesu for thy holy name& for thy bitter passionSaue vs fro
                    synne & shameand endles dampnacion

OxfNew310.Transcription:
Ihesu for thy holy nameAnd thy bitter passionsaue me fro synne
                    & shameand endles dampnacion& bring me to the blisthat
                    neuer schal mys amen
OxfNew310.Editions:
Coxe,  Henry Octavius. 
             Catalogus codicum mss. qui in collegiis aulisque
                oxoniensibus….
         Oxon: e Typographeo academico, 1852: 112.

CULAdd2829.Transcription:
Swete Ihesu for þi holy nameand for þi bittere
                    passiounsaue my body & my sowle from synne & schame& from
                    endeles dampnacion
CULAdd2829.Editions:
O’Mara,  Veronica M. 
             “A Middle English Versified Penance Composed of Popular Prayer
                Tags.” 
             Notes and Queries
         n.s. 33 [231] (1986): 449-50: 449.

CULEe420.Transcription:
Jhesus for thy holy nameand for thy Beter passionsaue vs frome
                    syne and shameand endles damnasion
CULEe420.Note:
Written as prose, with ‘swet Ihesus amen sic ego
                    dico’ at end.

CamMagPep1254.Transcription:
Ihesu for þi holy Name and þi bytter payssounsave may sol
                    from enles damnacioun
CamMagPep1254.Note:
Added to blank verso of last leaf, by a hand of sixteenth
                    century.

CamTCC1450.Transcription:
Jhesu ffor þi holy name& ffore thi byttyre
                    passion[sa]we vs ffrom syn & schame& ffrom endylys
                    [da]mpnaccion& brynge vs to the blysse[That] nevyr schall
                    mysseswyt Ihesu Amen
CamTCC1450.Note: Written as prose; part of page torn away.

BLAdd27924.Transcription:
Ihesu for thi holy nameAnd thi bittir passionSaue me from syn
                    and shameAnd endeles dampnacionAnd bryng me to thi blisseSwete
                    ihesu lord. AMEN

BLAru285.First Lines: Ihesu for thy haly nameAnd for thy bitter passioun…
BLAru285.Last Lines: …And bring ws vnto þe blissThat neuer sall haue end sueit Ihesus
BLAru285.Note: Six-line version; ends “Amen,” followed by further prose prayer in the same vein.
BLAru285.Attributed Title: Ane vthir orisoun To þe name of Ihesu (rubric, f. 178)
BLAru285.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of British Library Arundel MS 285.
         https://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?index=0&ref=Arundel_MS_285.
BLAru285.Editions:
Bennett,  Jack Arthur Walter,
                        ed.  
             Devotional Pieces in Verse and Prose from Ms. Arundel 285 and Ms.
                Harleian 6919.
Scottish Text Society
         3rd ser. 23. Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1955: 278.

BLHar63.Transcription:
Ihesus for þi holi nameAnd for þi lady
beter passionSchilde me from schame& ffrom endles
                    damnacion& bring me to þe blis þat neuer schal haue
                    end
BLHar63.Note:
Written sideways, top to bottom along the left (outer) margin by a later
                    hand, written as prose without marking verse line breaks; originally wrote
                    ‘lady’ for ‘beter’ and corrected above the
                    line.

BLHar494.Transcription:
O swete blessyd Ihesu for thy holy name& thy byttere
                    passionsave vs from synne & shame& endlese damnacion&
                    bryng vs to þi blysse
BLHar494.Note:
Written as prose; headed, ‘Here foloeth þe bedes of pardon
                    in englyshe of saynt gregori ys pytye’ (f. 105); ends ‘Amen’
                    written after last word; and below these words, ‘Thys forsayde verse ys
                    sayde on euery bede’ (f. 105).

BLHar2445.Transcription: Ihesu for þi holy nameand for þi bitter passyonSaue vs fro synne & schame& endles dampnacion…
BLHar2445.Note: Two more lines in prose follow, “And bryng vs to þi blesse þat neuer shall haue ende swete ihesu Amen.”

BLHar2851.Transcription: O ihesu for þi holy name& þi bittir passionsaue me fro synne & shame& endles dampnacion& bryng me to þi blisfor þi name swete ihesus ihesus lord…
BLHar2851.Note: Ends “Amen,” and followed by five further prayers in the same vein, all beginning “O swete ihesu,” not rhymed, “Oswete ihesu gyff me þi loue….”

BLSl747.Transcription:
Iesu for thy holy nameAnd for thy bytter passiounSaue me from
                    synne and schameAnd endeles dampnacion
BLSl747.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Popular Prayers in Middle English Verse.” 
             Modern Philology
         36 (1939): 337-50: 337.

Wellcome632.Editions:
Bliss,  Philip. 
             Reliquiae Hearnianae.
         London: J. Russel Smith, 1869: 1.193.
Sparrow-Simpson,  W. 
             “On a Magical Roll Preserved in the British Museum.” 
             Journal of the British Archaeological Association
         48 (1892): 38-54: 39.

WorcF172.Transcription:
Ihesu for thi holy nameAnd for thi bitter passiounkepe me from
                    synne and shameAnd endeles dampnaciounAnd bryng me to thi swete
                    blisseþat never shal have end swete Ihesu Ame
WorcF172.Note:
Six lines: quatrain, abab, and two unrhymed lines; written as
                    prose.

Yates.Editions:
Bateman,  William. 
             Billyng’s Five Wounds of Christ.
         Manchester: Dean, 1814. 
Axon,  William Edward Armytage. 
             “The Symbolism of the ‘Five Wounds of Christ’.” 
             Transactions of the Lancashire and Chesire Antiquarian Society
         10 (1892): 67-77: 74.

NijmegenUL194.Transcription:
O Ihesu for thy holy nameAnd for thy bitter passonSave us from
                    synne and shameAnd fro endles dampnacionAnd brynge us unto thy
                    blysSwete Ihesu whan thy wille ys. Amen
NijmegenUL194.Editions:
Connolly,  Margaret. 
             “Some Unrecorded Middle English Verse in a Nijmegen Manuscript.” 
             Notes & Queries
         46 (1999): 442-4: 442.

YaleBei410.Transcription:
Ihesu for thyne holy nameAnd for thy bytter passyonSaue vs frome
                    synne & shameAnd endeles dampnacyonAnd brynge vs to the
                    blysseThat neuer shall haue endeSwete Ihesus Amen
